title: PINPOINT PRECISION: Punctate Epithelial Erosions (PEE)
summary: Punctate epithelial erosions (PEE) are a hallmark clinical sign of ocular surface distress, characterized by the focal loss of individual corneal epithelial cells. These tiny, depressed spots serve as a critical diagnostic indicator for a wide range of underlying ophthalmic conditions.

content.explanation: S: Superior (SLK); T: Toxic (Medicamentosa); A: Aqueous Deficiency (Dry Eye); I: Inferior (Blepharitis); N: Neurotrophic Keratopathy.

sections.title: Management Strategy
content: Step 1: Identify and treat the primary underlying cause.
Step 2: Initiate intensive lubrication with preservative-free artificial tears.
Step 3: Apply nocturnal lubricating ointments for exposure-related cases.
Step 4: Discontinue any offending toxic topical medications.
Step 5: Consider a bandage contact lens for severe epithelial compromise.
Step 6: Monitor for secondary bacterial infection and provide prophylactic coverage if needed.

sections.title: URGENT RED FLAGS
content: Sudden, significant drop in Visual Acuity
Presence of a Hypopyon (white blood cells in anterior chamber)
Intense pain that is non-responsive to lubricants

sections.title: Clinical Summary Verbatim
sections.content: Punctate epithelial erosions are not a disease in themselves but a manifestation of ocular surface disease. They represent areas where the corneal epithelium has been shed. When viewed under a slit lamp with a cobalt blue filter after fluorescein instillation, they appear as bright green dots because the dye pools in the spaces where cells are missing. Management focuses on restoring the tear film and protecting the corneal surface to allow for re-epithelialization.
